titleInfo.title: LSU History Oral History Project: Religion at LSU
titleInfo.subTitle: Charles Wood oral history interview, 1992

name.description: Wood was born on 21 August 1932 in Syracuse, NY. He earned a bachelor of arts in 1954 from Cornell University then spent two years in the army. In 1966 he received a masters of divinity from Virginia Theological Seminary and, in 1973, completed a masters in sacred theology and Old Testament at Nashota House Seminary in Nashota, Wi. He began work as the chaplain of the St. Alban's Episcopal Church, which is located on the LSU campus, in 1970.

subject.topic: Saint Alban's Episcopal Church (Baton Rouge, La.)
Baton Rouge (La.)--Social life and customs--20th century.

mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special)
mods.accessCondition: Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright is retained by Louisiana State University in accordance with U.S. copyright laws.

"E-mail lsudiglib@lsu.edu with questions or comments. See instructions for ordering reprints of this audio here: http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special/services/duplication.html Mention the ""Item number"" or ""Item URL"" in your request. "
mods.abstract: Wood discusses his family and educational background. He recounts his decision to become a minister and the student activism at LSU in the 1970s, including his reasons for supporting student protesters. Wood also reminisces about his work as a counselor at the medical health center, incidents he has dealt with throughout his career, and his duties as pastor of St. Albans, including his day-to-day routine.
